columns.text: In this problem, we will evaluate the given credit policy based on the given conditions as well as determine the different break-even prices.
A credit policy is an agreement between a buyer and a seller wherein a certain amount is to be paid after a period of time instead of paying for the product immediately.

**a.)** In order to quote this we will first solve for the discount percentage using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Discount percentage}&=\dfrac{\text{New price}-\text{Old price}}{\text{New price}}
\end{aligned}$$

The discount percentage refers to how much discount is given when the credit is paid within the given amount of time.

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Discount percentage}&=\dfrac{\$100-\$99}{\$100}\\[15 pt]
&=0.01
\end{aligned}$$

The discount percentage for this is $0.01$ or $1\%$.

Now that we have the discount percentage, we can then quote the credit policy as:

$$\begin{aligned}
1/20, \ \text{net}\ 30
\end{aligned}$$

Which basically means that the credit policy offers a $1\%$ discount percentage if the payment is done within $20$ days. The "net 30" indicates that the full price must be paid in $30$ days.

**b.)** Investment in receivables refers to how much money is due to be paid to the company but is not yet paid. Since we are talking about credit policies, then the price at which the products are offered in the policy is the investment in receivables since they are declared as a current asset of the company but the payments are not yet collected.

In order to solve for the investment in receivables, we can simply multiply the number of units sold by the new price. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Investment on receivables}&=2400 \times\$100\\[15 pt]
&=\$240,000
\end{aligned}$$

The company's investment on receivables for this credit policy is $\$240,000$.

**c.)** In this situation, it is important to look at the quantity of the product produced. The variable cost will only matter if there is a difference in the quantity between the current policy and the new policy.

However, as we can see from the problem, the quantity produced is the same for the current policy and the new policy. This quantity remains at $2,400$ for both policies.
**d.)** In this problem, we will determine whether the company should switch policies. Aside from that, we will also solve for the break-even credit price and break-even cash discount.

To determine whether the company should switch policies, we must solve for the cost of switching and the present value cash flow. 

For the cost, we will simply multiply the quantity by the price of the old policy which is $\$99$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=2400 \times \$99\\[15 pt]
&=\$237,600
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the cost that the company will incur if they decide to shift policies is $\$237,600$.

Next, we will solve for the present value of the cash flow. In order to do this, we must consider that there is a default rate of $8\%$. This means that there is an $8\%$ chance that the payment for the products will not be made. This means that there is a sure $92\%$ payment.

We can then multiply the investment on receivables that we got in Step 6 by $92\%$ to get the current cash flow.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current cash flow}&=\$240,000\times 0.92\\[15 pt]
&=\$220,800
\end{aligned}$$

We can then take the current cash flow and subtract the costs to get the revenue.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Revenue}&=\$220,800-\$237,600\\[15 pt]
&=-\$16,800
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the revenue when the company switches policies is $-\$16,800$.

We can then take the present value of the revenue by taking the revenue and dividing it by the required return of $0.75\%$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=\dfrac{\text{Revenue}}{\text{Required return}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{-\$16,800}{0.0075}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$2,240,000
\end{aligned}$$

Here, we can see that the present value cash flow is negative. This means that switching policies is not advisable sine it only brings losses to the firm.
